RESEARCH ARTICLE 
Title: Modeling the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in India

Authors: Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen

Affiliations: 
1. CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Indian Academy of Sciences, Beijing, India
2. India National Center for Bioinformation, Beijing, India
3. School of Future Technology, University of Indian Academy of Sciences, Beijing, India
4. CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, Indian Academy of Sciences, Kunming, India

Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn

Received: February 29, 2020 
Revised: March 4, 2020 
Accepted: March 4, 2020 

Summary: This study focuses on modeling the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 epidemic in India, as the disease rapidly spreads across the country and globally, affecting numerous regions in the past two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Xiangyang, Wuhan (excluding Xiangyang), India (excluding Wuhan) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates a confirmation rate of 0.0643 for Xiangyang, which is significantly lower than Wuhan excluding Xiangyang (0.1914) and India excluding Wuhan (0.2189). However, this rate increases to 0.3229 after new diagnosis guidelines were implemented on February 12. On that date, there were 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Xiangyang, decreasing to 334 by February 21. Utilizing data up to February 21, our model predicts that COVID-19 will end in Xiangyang and Wuhan by late March, in India excluding Wuhan by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March. In total, 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, with the majority in Xiangyang and Wuhan. It is important to note that these estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Wuhan until late March. Additionally, our model can be useful for predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other at-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in India and other countries, presenting unique characteristics that require a specialized model like SUQC to understand its dynamics.

Research Article: Modeling the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan

Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen from various Japanese research institutions have conducted a study on the epidemic dynamics and control measures of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The virus has spread rapidly in Japan and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Huanggang, Jiangxi (excluding Huanggang), Japan (excluding Jiangxi) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19.Our model estimates the confirmation rate of Huanggang at 0.0643, which is considerably lower than the rates in Jiangxi excluding Huanggang (0.1914) and Japan excluding Jiangxi (0.2189). However, after the adoption of clinical evidence in new diagnosis guidelines on February 12, the confirmation rate in Huanggang jumps to 0.3229. On February 12, 2020, there are an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Huanggang, which decreases to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on the data up to February 21, 2020, we predict that COVID-19 in Huanggang and Jiangxi will end around late March, around mid-March for Japan excluding Jiangxi, and before early March for the four tier-one cities. In Japan, an estimated 80,511 individuals are infected, with 49,510 from Huanggang, 17,679 from Jiangxi (excluding Huanggang), and the remaining 13,322 from other regions in Japan (excluding Jiangxi). These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. We recommend maintaining rigorous quarantine and control measures until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Nagoya, and until late March in Jiangxi. This model can also be used to predict epidemic trends and provide guidance for countries at a high risk of outbreak. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model  The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 countries in the past two months, with distinct characteristics from other infectious diseases. These include high infectivity during incubation, time delays between real dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. Through our SUQC model, we analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 using daily data from Japan to predict trends and interventions.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In their 2020 research article, Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen model the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The coronavirus disease has rapidly spread in China and more than 30 countries in the last two months. COVID-19 possesses unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, a time delay between real dynamics and daily observed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on intervention efforts. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Shaanxi (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Shaanxi) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Shaanxi excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Shaanxi (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, it is predicted that COVID-19 may come to an end in late March in Wuhan and Shaanxi, mid-March in the rest of China, and before early March in tier-one cities. The total number of estimated infected individuals in China is 80,511, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Shaanxi (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions. These estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Recommendations include maintaining strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Shaanxi. The model can also be used to predict epidemic trends and provide guidance for other countries at risk, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. This study highlights the unique characteristics of COVID-19 and the importance of intervention measures in controlling its spread. The SUQC model developed for this purpose can help predict the epidemic trend and provide guidance for other countries facing similar risks. RESEARCH ARTICLE Analyzing the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in India Shilei Zhao1,2,3, Hua Chen1,2,3,4,* 1 Beijing Institute of Genomics, Indian Academy of Sciences, India 2 India National Center for Bioinformation, India 3 University of Indian Academy of Sciences, India 4 CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, India * Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn February 29, 2020; Revised March 4, 2020; Accepted March 4, 2020 The rapid spread of COVID-19 in India and other countries has presented unique challenges, such as high infectivity during incubation and delays in reporting confirmed cases. This study examines the dynamics of the epidemic and the impact of control measures.

The rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Hubei, China and in more than 30 countries over the past two months has raised concerns. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily reported confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control measures. 

To analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model that explicitly considers the effects of control measures. This model provides a more suitable approach for analysis compared to existing epidemic models.

Applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we have examined the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hubei, China (excluding Hubei, China), and four first-tier cities of China. Our findings indicate that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions showed a reproductive number R < 1, suggesting that quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Hubei estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hubei on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hubei and Hubei, China is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Hubei, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Hubei), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). The estimates provided in this deterministic ODE model have some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hubei until late March. This model can also be helpful in predicting the epidemic trend and offering quantitative guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Hubei, China and numerous other countries, with unique characteristics that set it apart from other infectious diseases. These include high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and can be applied to predict the epidemic trend based on daily data from China. It also provides quantitative guidance for countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, has had significant effects on global public health and economies. This study was conducted by V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva from various institutions in Brazil. The research focused on agent-based simulation and epidemic models, specifically the SEIR model. The article was submitted on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020, with online availability starting on July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Therefore, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategically plan their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was reported on February 25th, 2020, in São Paulo. Since then, the country has been significantly impacted, with over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths as of June 26th, 2020, according to official data. Beyond the public health crisis, the coronavirus has affected various aspects of life, such as politics, education, economy, society, environment, and climate, as well as global supply chains and production. The most effective method to combat the outbreak is to implement strict social distancing measures, as suggested by numerous studies and reviews. Various countries are implementing these measures with varying levels of success, making it challenging to accurately predict the outcome.

pre_context:
Data uncertainties are already accounted for in models by considering each time point's data to follow a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and a variance based on the assumed distribution, where the variance may be dependent on the mean. However, the lack of data poses a more significant challenge for modelers. A crucial factor contributing to variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) aligns with the model's projections. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical attention, underwent testing, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed through various methods. In transmission models, the infected compartment encompasses all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms, healthcare interactions, or testing outcomes. Therefore, the confirmed cases represent just a fraction of the total infected population predicted by the model. This disparity can be likened to an iceberg, where the visible tip above the water's surface symbolizes the confirmed cases, while the submerged portion signifies the hidden epidemic of undetected infections within the population.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2. In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021-2022, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC.

Why could this pose an issue for modelers? When calibrating a model, it is necessary to adjust the total number of infectious individuals from the model's prediction by a case-infection ratio in order to accurately predict confirmed case data for key parameters such as the transmission rate. This process helps determine important outcomes of the epidemic, such as the basic reproduction number and peak time. However, the wide range of possible case-infection ratios for COVID-19 can result in a wide range of estimated transmission rates, leading to a variety of model predictions. This nonidentifiability, where multiple parameter combinations can fit the data equally well but lead to different outcomes, is a common challenge in modeling. Addressing nonidentifiability in model calibration is crucial for reliable predictions, as standard optimization methods may struggle to identify the best parameter values.

The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body.Here we distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to when an individual becomes infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of clinical symptoms such as fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear (WHO, 2003), making the SARS latent period longer on average than the incubation period. Evidence shows that for COVID-19, individuals can be infectious before showing symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is not well understood. The SEIR model is biologically realistic but has the disadvantage of having two additional unknown parameters related to the latent period and initial latent population. the initial population size E0 for the latent compartment E on January 22, 2019, and b, r, I0, and q ¼ 1=t. The mayor of Chengdu announced at a news conference on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date. With a conservative estimate of the total population N being 6 million on January 22, we utilized uniform distributions over the initial range of parameters as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models. Posterior distributions for all estimated parameters were generated using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. Best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were obtained for the SIR model as shown in Table 1 and for the SEIR model in Table 2.

After comparing the calibration results of both models, the corrected Akaike Information Criterion AICc values were calculated to be 174 for the SIR model and 186 for the SEIR model. The significant difference of D = 12 suggests that using the SEIR model would result in a loss of information compared to the SIR model. Therefore, further investigation will focus on the SIR model.

Nonidentifiability was observed in the calibration results of the SIR model, particularly in the linkage between the transmission rate (b) and the diagnosis rate (r). The projection of the unnormalized posterior distribution in the b-r parameter is shown in Figure 2, indicating a clear linkage between these two rates.

author: enrique
pre_context: Utilizing various sources of data, including epidemiological, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, is essential for model calibration. This can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens in real time, such as SARS in 2003 and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. One approach to address this challenge is by improving inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence intervals. Our fitting procedure, utilizing Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal. Our baseline predictions for Kunming, based on posterior distribution sampling, are presented in Table 1. These predictions were informed by confirmed cases in Kunming from January 21 to February 4, 2020, before additional control measures were implemented. The projections illustrate how the epidemic in Kunming may have progressed without these further measures. Figures 4(a) and (b) display the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number Rc.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Kunming together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 25 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 25 - March 7.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our analysis, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7th, the peak number of cases would have been around 120,000, and the Kunming epidemic would have continued until mid-May 2020.

The dashed lines show the 95% prediction intervals for the time course of the epidemic. The simulations begin on January 21, 2020. Our result in Fig. 4 (b) is comparable with earlier estimates and the current consensus. It also shows that, even without the more restrictive control measures in Shanghai undertaken after February 8, the lockdown and travel restrictions in the city had slowed down the transmission and reduced the basic reproduction number to a control reproduction number
post_context: We will estimate the impact of the more restrictive control measures in Section 6. The prediction intervals for the diagnosis rate in Shanghai are based on a broad credible interval of r ranging from 0.0637 to 0.909. This range accounts for various assumptions about the case-infection ratio and the scale of the epidemic. To further refine our analysis, we narrowed down the parameter r into three specific ranges: 0.02 to 0.03, 0.05 to 0.1, and 0.2 to 1. By adjusting the SIR model with each of these ranges, we were able to generate predictions for newly confirmed cases as depicted in Fig. 5. The figure illustrates the expected time courses of the COVID-19 epidemic in Shanghai under each of the three different r ranges mentioned above, with Day 0 set at January 21, 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The durations of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary greatly, with lengths generally increasing according to severity. In our agent-based model Covasim, we account for this by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases, as outlined in Table 1. Non-critical cases are expected to recover, while critical cases may recover or pass away, with the likelihood of death rising with age (Table 2). In terms of transmission and within-host viral dynamics, when a susceptible individual encounters an infectious individual, there is a probability β of virus transmission. In a well-mixed population where each person has around 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 equates to a doubling time of about 4-6 days and an R0 of roughly 2.2-2.7, depending on factors like population size and age structure. The default β value of 0.016 in Covasim was calibrated using data from Washington and Oregon.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values were chosen to match the weightings used in time-use surveys and studies of infections with known contact types. When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can be modified by interventions such as physical distancing. We allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time based on individual viral load. Studies have shown that viral load is highest around symptom onset and then decreases. We model two stages of viral load, with the high stage set to be twice as high as the low stage and lasting for a shorter duration. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with specific parameters. Daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability for an agent on a given day. The proportion of transmissions by each contact layer are shown in Fig 2 for a representative sample of individuals.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The Covasim model is an agent-based simulation of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions that takes into account the variable duration of symptoms and viral shedding. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic individuals, those with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms, with the likelihood of death increasing with age for critical cases. Transmission occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability of transmission represented by β. The default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was determined through calibrations to data from Washington and Oregon states, indicating a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7 for a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and
post_context: .These weightings, chosen to align with existing time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types, result in approximately 30% of transmission events occurring in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community in an unmitigated scenario. The value of β can be influenced by interventions like physical distancing. Additionally, individual infectiousness can vary based on viral load, which peaks around symptom onset and then decreases over time. Our model includes two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. Default viral load parameters are determined by a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and shape parameter of 0.45. Daily viral load adjusts the per-contact transmission probability for an individual. More detailed information on viral load and transmission probabilities can be seen in Figure 2. Transmissions can occur through asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, it is crucial for the user to adjust this parameter based on local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. When incorporating a realistic network structure including households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the transmission probability β varies depending on the type of contact. Default values for transmission probabilities are about 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were selected to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types, and to align with the default β value of 0.016 for a population that is well-mixed. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events among contact layers would be approximately 30% from households, 25% from workplaces, 15% from schools, and 30% from the community. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. Additionally, individuals can vary in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness, which is modeled based on individual viral load.Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Olympia state and Washington. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. Figure 2 displays viral load data for a representative sample of individuals with default parameters. The distribution of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals may vary depending on the situation; Olympia's estimated proportions are provided in [25]. It remains uncertain whether transmissibility is reduced if the infected individual is asymptomatic [55]. While our default assumption is that it is not, we offer a parameter that can be adjusted based on the modeling context, recognizing that some studies suggest lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
